pli-tv-kd8:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
pli-tv-kd8:1.1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.

pli-tv-kd8:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vesālī iddhā ceva hoti phitā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca;
pli-tv-kd8:1.1.2.eng: At that time Vesālī was prosperous and crowded with people, and there was plenty of food.

pli-tv-kd8:1.1.3.pli: satta ca pāsādasahassāni satta ca pāsādasatāni satta ca pāsādā;
pli-tv-kd8:1.1.3.eng: There were seven thousand seven hundred and seven stilt houses,

pli-tv-kd8:1.1.4.pli: satta ca kūṭāgārasahassāni satta ca kūṭāgārasatāni satta ca kūṭāgārāni;
pli-tv-kd8:1.1.4.eng: and the same number of halls with peaked roofs,

pli-tv-kd8:1.1.5.pli: satta ca ārāmasahassāni satta ca ārāmasatāni satta ca ārāmā;

pli-tv-kd8:1.1.6.pli: satta ca pokkharaṇīsahassāni satta ca pokkharaṇīsatāni satta ca pokkharaṇiyo;

pli-tv-kd8:1.1.7.pli: ambapālī ca gaṇikā abhirūpā hoti dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā, padakkhiṇā nacce ca gīte ca vādite ca, abhisaṭā atthikānaṃ atthikānaṃ manussānaṃ paññāsāya ca rattiṃ gacchati;
pli-tv-kd8:1.1.7.eng: And there was the courtesan Ambapālī who was attractive and gracious and had the most beautiful complexion. She was skilled in dancing, singing, and instrumental music. She was highly desired, charging fifty coins for a night.

pli-tv-kd8:1.1.8.pli: tāya ca vesālī bhiyyoso mattāya upasobhati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.1.8.eng: Because of her, Vesālī was even more splendid.

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.1.pli: Atha kho rājagahako negamo vesāliṃ agamāsi kenacideva karaṇīyena.
pli-tv-kd8:1.2.1.eng: On one occasion the householder association of Rājagaha traveled to Vesālī on business,
pli-tv-kd8:1.2.1.comm: Sp 3.326: Negamoti kuṭumbiyagaṇo, “Negama: a group of householders.” This definition is missing in DOP.

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.2.pli: Addasā kho rājagahako negamo vesāliṃ iddhañceva phitañca bahujanañca ākiṇṇamanussañca subhikkhañca;
pli-tv-kd8:1.2.2.eng: and they saw all these marvelous qualities of the city,

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.3.pli: satta ca pāsādasahassāni satta ca pāsādasatāni satta ca pāsāde;

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.4.pli: satta ca kūṭāgārasahassāni satta ca kūṭāgārasatāni satta ca kūṭāgārāni;

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.5.pli: satta ca ārāmasahassāni satta ca ārāmasatāni satta ca ārāme;

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.6.pli: satta ca pokkharaṇīsahassāni satta ca pokkharaṇīsatāni satta ca pokkharaṇiyo;

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.7.pli: ambapāliñca gaṇikaṃ abhirūpaṃ dassanīyaṃ pāsādikaṃ paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgataṃ, padakkhiṇaṃ nacce ca gīte ca vādite ca, abhisaṭaṃ atthikānaṃ atthikānaṃ manussānaṃ paññāsāya ca rattiṃ gacchantiṃ, tāya ca vesāliṃ bhiyyoso mattāya upasobhantiṃ.

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.8.pli: Atha kho rājagahako negamo vesāliyaṃ taṃ karaṇīyaṃ tīretvā punadeva rājagahaṃ paccāgañchi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.2.8.eng: When they had concluded their business, they returned to Rājagaha.

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.9.pli: Yena rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ seniyaṃ bimbisāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.2.9.eng: They then went to King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.10.pli: “vesālī, deva, iddhā ceva phitā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca;
pli-tv-kd8:1.2.10.eng: and told him about everything they had seen,

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.12.pli: tāya ca vesālī bhiyyoso mattāya upasobhati.

pli-tv-kd8:1.2.14.pli: “Tena hi, bhaṇe, tādisiṃ kumāriṃ jānātha yaṃ tumhe gaṇikaṃ vuṭṭhāpeyyāthā”ti.

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahe sālavatī nāma kumārī abhirūpā hoti dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā.
pli-tv-kd8:1.3.1.eng: At that time in Rājagaha there was a girl called Sālavatī who was attractive and gracious and had the most beautiful complexion,

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.2.pli: Atha kho rājagahako negamo sālavatiṃ kumāriṃ gaṇikaṃ vuṭṭhāpesi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.3.2.eng: and the householder association appointed her as courtesan.

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.3.pli: Atha kho sālavatī gaṇikā nacirasseva padakkhiṇā ahosi nacce ca gīte ca vādite ca, abhisaṭā atthikānaṃ atthikānaṃ manussānaṃ paṭisatena ca rattiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.3.3.eng: Soon afterwards she became skilled in dancing, singing, and instrumental music. She was highly desired, charging a hundred coins for a night.

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.4.pli: Atha kho sālavatī gaṇikā nacirasseva gabbhinī ahosi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.7.eng: If anyone finds out about this,

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.8.pli: sālavatī gaṇikā gabbhinīti, sabbo me sakkāro bhañjissati.

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.9.eng: Let me announce that I’m sick.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.10.pli: Atha kho sālavatī gaṇikā dovārikaṃ āṇāpesi—

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.12.eng: If anyone asks for me, tell them I’m sick.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.3.13.pli: “Evaṃ, ayye”ti kho so dovāriko sālavatiyā gaṇikāya paccassosi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.1.pli: Atha kho sālavatī gaṇikā tassa gabbhassa paripākamanvāya puttaṃ vijāyi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.4.1.eng: Her pregnancy progressed, and eventually she gave birth to a son.

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.2.pli: Atha kho sālavatī gaṇikā dāsiṃ āṇāpesi—

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.3.pli: “handa, je, imaṃ dārakaṃ kattarasuppe pakkhipitvā nīharitvā saṅkārakūṭe chaḍḍehī”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.4.3.eng: “Listen, take this boy away in a winnowing basket and throw him on the trash heap.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.4.pli: “Evaṃ, ayye”ti kho sā dāsī sālavatiyā gaṇikāya paṭissutvā taṃ dārakaṃ kattarasuppe pakkhipitvā nīharitvā saṅkārakūṭe chaḍḍesi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.4.4.eng: Saying, “Yes, ma’am,” she did just that.

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena abhayo nāma rājakumāro kālasseva rājupaṭṭhānaṃ gacchanto addasa taṃ dārakaṃ kākehi samparikiṇṇaṃ, disvāna manusse pucchi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.4.5.eng: On the same morning, as Prince Abhaya was walking to an audience with the king, he saw that boy surrounded by crows. He asked his companions,

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.10.pli: “Tena hi, bhaṇe, taṃ dārakaṃ amhākaṃ antepuraṃ netvā dhātīnaṃ detha posetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.4.10.eng: “Well then, take him to our compound and give him to the wet-nurses to feed.”
pli-tv-kd8:1.4.10.comm: “Compound” renders antepura. See Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.11.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho te manussā abhayassa rājakumārassa paṭissutvā taṃ dārakaṃ abhayassa rājakumārassa antepuraṃ netvā dhātīnaṃ adaṃsu—

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.13.eng: When they knew that he would live, they gave him the name Jīvaka, “Survivor”.

pli-tv-kd8:1.4.14.eng: And because a prince brought him up, they also gave him the name Komārabhacca, “Prince-reared”.

pli-tv-kd8:1.5.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco nacirasseva viññutaṃ pāpuṇi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.5.1.eng: When Jīvaka reached the age of discernment,

pli-tv-kd8:1.5.2.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco yena abhayo rājakumāro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā abhayaṃ rājakumāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.5.2.eng: he went to Prince Abhaya and asked him,

pli-tv-kd8:1.5.3.eng: “Who, sir, are my mother and father?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.5.4.pli: “Ahampi kho te, bhaṇe jīvaka, mātaraṃ na jānāmi;
pli-tv-kd8:1.5.4.eng: “I don’t know who your mother is,

pli-tv-kd8:1.5.7.eng: On a later occasion Jīvaka thought,

pli-tv-kd8:1.5.8.pli: “imāni kho rājakulāni na sukarāni asippena upajīvituṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.5.8.eng: “It’s not easy to make a living in a royal family without a profession.

pli-tv-kd8:1.5.9.eng: Why don’t I learn a profession?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.5.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena takkasilāyaṃ disāpāmokkho vejjo paṭivasati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.5.10.eng: At that time the pre-eminent physician in the world was living at Takkasilā.

pli-tv-kd8:1.6.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco abhayaṃ rājakumāraṃ anāpucchā yena takkasilā tena pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.6.1.eng: Then, without asking permission from Prince Abhaya, Jīvaka left for Takkasilā.

pli-tv-kd8:1.6.2.pli: Anupubbena yena takkasilā, yena vejjo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ vejjaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.6.2.eng: When he eventually arrived, he went to that physician and said,

pli-tv-kd8:1.6.3.eng: “Teacher, I wish to learn the profession.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.6.5.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco bahuñca gaṇhāti lahuñca gaṇhāti suṭṭhu ca upadhāreti, gahitañcassa na sammussati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.6.5.eng: Jīvaka learned much, and he learned quickly; he remembered well and did not forget.

pli-tv-kd8:1.6.6.pli: Atha kho jīvakassa komārabhaccassa sattannaṃ vassānaṃ accayena etadahosi—

pli-tv-kd8:1.6.7.pli: “ahaṃ kho bahuñca gaṇhāmi lahuñca gaṇhāmi suṭṭhu ca upadhāremi, gahitañca me na sammussati, satta ca me vassāni adhīyantassa, nayimassa sippassa anto paññāyati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.6.7.eng: “I’m a good learner, and I’ve been studying for seven years.

pli-tv-kd8:1.6.8.eng: And yet there’s no end in sight to learning this profession.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.7.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco yena so vejjo tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā taṃ vejjaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.7.1.eng: He went to that physician and told him what he had thought,

pli-tv-kd8:1.7.2.pli: “ahaṃ kho, ācariya, bahuñca gaṇhāmi lahuñca gaṇhāmi suṭṭhu ca upadhāremi, gahitañca me na sammussati, satta ca me vassāni adhīyantassa, nayimassa sippassa anto paññāyati.

pli-tv-kd8:1.7.3.eng: adding, “When will I complete the training for this profession?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.7.4.pli: “Tena hi, bhaṇe jīvaka, khaṇittiṃ ādāya takkasilāya samantā yojanaṃ āhiṇḍitvā yaṃ kiñci abhesajjaṃ passeyyāsi taṃ āharā”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.7.4.eng: “Listen, Jīvaka. Take a spade and walk as far as 13 kilometers all around Takkasilā and bring back whatever plant you see that’s not medicinal.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.7.5.pli: “Evaṃ, ācariyā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco tassa vejjassa paṭissutvā khaṇittiṃ ādāya takkasilāya samantā yojanaṃ āhiṇḍanto na kiñci abhesajjaṃ addasa.
pli-tv-kd8:1.7.5.eng: Saying, “Yes, teacher,” he did just that. But he did not see any plant that was not medicinal.

pli-tv-kd8:1.7.6.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco yena so vejjo tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā taṃ vejjaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.7.6.eng: He then went back to the physician and told him what had happened.

pli-tv-kd8:1.7.7.pli: “āhiṇḍantomhi, ācariya, takkasilāya samantā yojanaṃ, na kiñci abhesajjaṃ addasan”ti.

pli-tv-kd8:1.7.9.pli: Alaṃ te ettakaṃ jīvikāyā”ti jīvakassa komārabhaccassa parittaṃ pātheyyaṃ pādāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.7.9.eng: It’s enough for you to live on.” And he gave Jīvaka a small amount of provisions for the journey.

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco taṃ parittaṃ pātheyyaṃ ādāya yena rājagahaṃ tena pakkāmi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.2.pli: Atha kho jīvakassa komārabhaccassa taṃ parittaṃ pātheyyaṃ antarāmagge sākete parikkhayaṃ agamāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.8.2.eng: but the provisions were exhausted by the time he got to Sāketa.

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.4.pli: “ime kho maggā kantārā appodakā appabhakkhā, na sukarā apātheyyena gantuṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.8.4.eng: “These roads go through the wilderness where there’s little water and little food. It’s not easy to travel there without provisions.

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.6.0.eng: 2. The account of the wealthy merchant’s wife

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sākete seṭṭhibhariyāya sattavassiko sīsābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.8.6.1.eng: At that time in Sāketa there was a wealthy merchant whose wife had had a headache for seven years.

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.7.pli: Bahū mahantā mahantā disāpāmokkhā vejjā āgantvā nāsakkhiṃsu arogaṃ kātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.8.7.eng: Many of the most famous physicians in the world had come to see her, but none was able to cure her.

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.9.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco sāketaṃ pavisitvā manusse pucchi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.8.9.eng: When Jīvaka arrived at Sāketa, he asked people,

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.10.eng: “Is there anyone who’s sick who I might treat?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.8.11.eng: “There’s a wealthy merchant whose wife has had a headache for seven years.

pli-tv-kd8:1.9.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco yena seṭṭhissa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā dovārikaṃ āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.9.1.eng: Jīvaka went to that merchant’s house and told the doorman,

pli-tv-kd8:1.9.2.eng: “Go and say this to the merchant’s wife,

pli-tv-kd8:1.9.3.eng: Ma’am, a doctor has arrived. He wishes to see you.’”

pli-tv-kd8:1.9.4.pli: “Evaṃ, ācariyā”ti kho so dovāriko jīvakassa komārabhaccassa paṭissutvā yena seṭṭhibhariyā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā seṭṭhibhariyaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.9.4.eng: Saying, “Yes, doctor,” he did as asked.

pli-tv-kd8:1.9.7.eng: She replied, “What sort of doctor is it?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.9.9.pli: “Alaṃ, bhaṇe dovārika, kiṃ me daharako vejjo karissati?
pli-tv-kd8:1.9.9.eng: “Forget it. I don’t need a young doctor.

pli-tv-kd8:1.9.10.pli: Bahū mahantā mahantā disāpāmokkhā vejjā āgantvā nāsakkhiṃsu arogaṃ kātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.9.10.eng: Many of the most famous physicians in the world have been here, but none was able to cure me.

pli-tv-kd8:1.9.11.eng: And they were very expensive too.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.1.pli: Atha kho so dovāriko yena jīvako komārabhacco tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.10.1.eng: The doorman then returned to Jīvaka and told him what the merchant’s wife had said.

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.3.pli: ‘alaṃ, bhaṇe dovārika, kiṃ me daharako vejjo karissati?

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.4.pli: Bahū mahantā mahantā disāpāmokkhā vejjā āgantvā nāsakkhiṃsu arogaṃ kātuṃ.

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.8.pli: mā kira, ayye, pure kiñci adāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.10.8.eng: that she doesn’t have to pay anything in advance.

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.9.pli: Yadā arogā ahosi tadā yaṃ iccheyyāsi taṃ dajjeyyāsī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.10.9.eng: When she is cured, she can pay whatever she likes.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.10.pli: “Evaṃ, ācariyā”ti kho so dovāriko jīvakassa komārabhaccassa paṭissutvā yena seṭṭhibhariyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā seṭṭhibhariyaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.10.10.eng: Saying, “Yes, doctor,” he told the merchant’s wife.

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.13.pli: Yadā arogā ahosi tadā yaṃ iccheyyāsi taṃ dajjeyyāsī’”ti.

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.14.eng: She said, “Well then, let him in.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.10.15.pli: “Evaṃ, ayye”ti kho so dovāriko seṭṭhibhariyāya paṭissutvā yena jīvako komārabhacco tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.10.15.eng: Saying, “Yes, ma’am,” he went to Jīvaka and told him.

pli-tv-kd8:1.11.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco yena seṭṭhibhariyā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā seṭṭhibhariyāya vikāraṃ sallakkhetvā seṭṭhibhariyaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.11.1.eng: Jīvaka then approached the merchant’s wife. After examining her, he said to her,

pli-tv-kd8:1.11.2.eng: “Ma’am, I need a handful of ghee.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.11.3.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhibhariyā jīvakassa komārabhaccassa pasataṃ sappiṃ dāpesi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.11.3.eng: She got him a handful of ghee.

pli-tv-kd8:1.11.4.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco taṃ pasataṃ sappiṃ nānābhesajjehi nippacitvā seṭṭhibhariyaṃ mañcake uttānaṃ nipātetvā natthuto adāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.11.4.eng: Jīvaka cooked that ghee with a number of medicines. He then had her lie down on her back on a bed, and he gave her the medicine through the nose.

pli-tv-kd8:1.11.5.pli: Atha kho taṃ sappi natthuto dinnaṃ mukhato uggañchi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.11.5.eng: The medicine emerged in her mouth.

pli-tv-kd8:1.11.6.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhibhariyā paṭiggahe niṭṭhubhitvā dāsiṃ āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.11.6.eng: She then spat it out into a container and told a slave,

pli-tv-kd8:1.11.7.eng: “Listen, save this ghee in a cotton wad.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.2.pli: “acchariyaṃ yāva lūkhāyaṃ gharaṇī, yatra hi nāma imaṃ chaḍḍanīyadhammaṃ sappiṃ picunā gāhāpessati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.12.2.eng: “It’s astonishing how wretched this housewife is in saving this ghee in a cotton wad, when it should be discarded.

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.3.pli: Bahukāni ca me mahagghāni bhesajjāni upagatāni.
pli-tv-kd8:1.12.3.eng: Many of my valuable medicines went into it,

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.4.eng: but she might not give me anything for my services.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.5.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhibhariyā jīvakassa komārabhaccassa vikāraṃ sallakkhetvā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.12.5.eng: Seeing his body language, the merchant’s wife asked him

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.8.pli: “acchariyaṃ yāva lūkhāyaṃ gharaṇī, yatra hi nāma imaṃ chaḍḍanīyadhammaṃ sappiṃ picunā gāhāpessati.

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.9.pli: Bahukāni ca me mahagghāni bhesajjāni upagatāni.

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.11.pli: “Mayaṃ kho, ācariya, āgārikā nāma upajānāmetassa saṃyamassa.
pli-tv-kd8:1.12.11.eng: and she said, “We householders know the benefit of such frugality.

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.12.pli: Varametaṃ sappi dāsānaṃ vā kammakarānaṃ vā pādabbhañjanaṃ vā padīpakaraṇe vā āsittaṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.12.12.eng: This ghee is good for the slaves and workers, for ointment for the feet, or for using in lamps.

pli-tv-kd8:1.12.13.pli: Mā kho tvaṃ, ācariya, vimano ahosi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco seṭṭhibhariyāya sattavassikaṃ sīsābādhaṃ ekeneva natthukammena apakaḍḍhi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.13.1.eng: Jīvaka cured the headache of the merchant’s wife with a single treatment through the nose.

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.2.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhibhariyā arogā samānā jīvakassa komārabhaccassa cattāri sahassāni pādāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.13.2.eng: When she was well, she gave him four thousand coins.

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.4.pli: “mātā me arogā ṭhitā”ti cattāri sahassāni pādāsi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.6.pli: “sassu me arogā ṭhitā”ti cattāri sahassāni pādāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.13.6.eng: found out that she was well, they too gave him four thousand coins each,

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.8.pli: “bhariyā me arogā ṭhitā”ti cattāri sahassāni pādāsi dāsañca dāsiñca assarathañca.
pli-tv-kd8:1.13.8.eng: The merchant also gave him a male and a female slave, and a carriage with horses.

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.9.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco tāni soḷasasahassāni ādāya dāsañca dāsiñca assarathañca yena rājagahaṃ tena pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.13.9.eng: Jīvaka took those sixteen thousand coins, as well as the male and female slaves and the carriage with horses, and he left for Rājagaha.

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.10.pli: Anupubbena yena rājagahaṃ yena abhayo rājakumāro tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā abhayaṃ rājakumāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.13.10.eng: When he eventually arrived, he went to Prince Abhaya and said,

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.11.pli: “idaṃ me, deva, paṭhamakammaṃ soḷasasahassāni dāso ca dāsī ca assaratho ca.
pli-tv-kd8:1.13.11.eng: “For my first job, sir, I earned sixteen thousand coins, a male and a female slave, and a carriage with horses.

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.12.eng: Please accept it for bringing me up.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.15.eng: But please build a house in our compound.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.13.16.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco abhayassa rājakumārassa paṭissutvā abhayassa rājakumārassa antepure nivesanaṃ māpesi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa bhagandalābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.14.1.eng: At that time King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha had hemorrhoids.

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.2.eng: His wrap garments were soiled with blood,

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.3.eng: and the queens made fun of him,

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.4.pli: “utunī dāni devo, pupphaṃ devassa uppannaṃ, na ciraṃ devo vijāyissatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.14.4.eng: “Sir, you’re menstruating; your fertile period has arrived. Soon you’ll give birth.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.6.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro abhayaṃ rājakumāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.14.6.eng: Soon afterwards he told Prince Abhaya what had happened,

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.7.pli: “mayhaṃ kho, bhaṇe abhaya, tādiso ābādho, sāṭakā lohitena makkhiyanti, deviyo maṃ disvā uppaṇḍenti—

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.8.pli: ‘utunī dāni devo, pupphaṃ devassa uppannaṃ, na ciraṃ devo vijāyissatī’ti.

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.9.pli: Iṅgha, bhaṇe abhaya, tādisaṃ vejjaṃ jānāhi yo maṃ tikiccheyyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.14.9.eng: adding, “Abhaya, please find a doctor to treat me.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.10.pli: “Ayaṃ, deva, amhākaṃ jīvako vejjo taruṇo bhadrako.
pli-tv-kd8:1.14.10.eng: “Sir, our young doctor Jīvaka is excellent.

pli-tv-kd8:1.14.12.pli: “Tena hi, bhaṇe abhaya, jīvakaṃ vejjaṃ āṇāpehi;

pli-tv-kd8:1.15.1.pli: Atha kho abhayo rājakumāro jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.15.1.eng: Prince Abhaya then sent for Jīvaka.

pli-tv-kd8:1.15.3.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco abhayassa rājakumārassa paṭissutvā nakhena bhesajjaṃ ādāya yena rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ seniyaṃ bimbisāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.15.3.eng: Saying, “Yes, sir,” Jīvaka took some medicine on his nail and went to King Bimbisāra. He said,

pli-tv-kd8:1.15.5.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa bhagandalābādhaṃ ekeneva ālepena apakaḍḍhi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.15.5.eng: Jīvaka then cured King Bimbisāra’s hemorrhoids with one application of ointment.

pli-tv-kd8:1.15.6.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro arogo samāno pañca itthisatāni sabbālaṅkāraṃ bhūsāpetvā omuñcāpetvā puñjaṃ kārāpetvā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.15.6.eng: When the king was well, he had five hundred women adorned with every kind of ornament. He then had the ornaments removed and made into a pile. And he said to Jīvaka,

pli-tv-kd8:1.15.7.pli: “etaṃ, bhaṇe jīvaka, pañcannaṃ itthisatānaṃ sabbālaṅkāraṃ tuyhaṃ hotū”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.15.7.eng: “Jīvaka, these ornaments from five hundred women are all yours.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.15.8.eng: “There’s no need. Please just remember my act of service.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.15.9.pli: “Tena hi, bhaṇe jīvaka, maṃ upaṭṭhaha, itthāgārañca, buddhappamukhañca bhikkhusaṅghan”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.15.9.eng: “Well then, Jīvaka, please attend on me, the harem, and the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.15.10.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa paccassosi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.0.eng: 4. The account of the wealthy merchant of Rājagaha

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa sattavassiko sīsābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.16.1.eng: At that time a wealthy merchant of Rājagaha had had a headache for seven years.

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.2.pli: Bahū mahantā mahantā disāpāmokkhā vejjā āgantvā nāsakkhiṃsu arogaṃ kātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.16.2.eng: Many of the most famous physicians in the world had come to see him, but none was able to cure him.

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.4.eng: yet they gave up on him.

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.6.eng: “The merchant will die in five days.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.8.eng: “The merchant will die in seven days.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.9.eng: The householder association of Rājagaha considered,

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.10.pli: “ayaṃ kho seṭṭhi gahapati bahūpakāro rañño ceva negamassa ca.
pli-tv-kd8:1.16.10.eng: “This merchant has done much for the king and for this association,

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.11.eng: and now the doctors have given up on him.

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.16.pli: Ayañca rañño jīvako vejjo taruṇo bhadrako.
pli-tv-kd8:1.16.16.eng: But there’s Jīvaka, the king’s excellent young doctor.

pli-tv-kd8:1.16.17.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ rājānaṃ jīvakaṃ vejjaṃ yāceyyāma seṭṭhiṃ gahapatiṃ tikicchitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.16.17.eng: Let’s ask the king for Jīvaka to treat the merchant.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.17.1.pli: Atha kho rājagahako negamo yena rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ seniyaṃ bimbisāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.17.1.eng: They then went to the king and told him about the merchant,

pli-tv-kd8:1.17.2.pli: “ayaṃ, deva, seṭṭhi gahapati bahūpakāro devassa ceva negamassa ca;

pli-tv-kd8:1.17.8.pli: Sādhu devo jīvakaṃ vejjaṃ āṇāpetu seṭṭhiṃ gahapatiṃ tikicchitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.17.8.eng: adding, “Sir, please ask doctor Jīvaka to treat the merchant.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.17.9.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.17.9.eng: And that’s what the king did.

pli-tv-kd8:1.17.11.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa paṭissutvā yena seṭṭhi gahapati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā seṭṭhissa gahapatissa vikāraṃ sallakkhetvā seṭṭhiṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.17.11.eng: Saying, “Yes, sir,” Jīvaka went to that merchant, examined him, and said,

pli-tv-kd8:1.17.12.pli: “sace tvaṃ, gahapati, arogo bhaveyyāsi, kiṃ me assa deyyadhammo”ti?
pli-tv-kd8:1.17.12.eng: “If I were to cure you, what fee would you pay me?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.17.13.pli: “Sabbaṃ sāpateyyañca te, ācariya, hotu, ahañca te dāso”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.17.13.eng: “I would give you all my wealth, doctor, and I would become your slave.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.1.pli: “Sakkhissasi pana tvaṃ, gahapati, ekena passena sattamāse nipajjitun”ti?
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.1.eng: “Are you able to lie on one side for seven months?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.3.pli: “Sakkhissasi pana tvaṃ, gahapati, dutiyena passena sattamāse nipajjitun”ti?
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.3.eng: “Are you able to lie on the other side for seven months?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.5.pli: “Sakkhissasi pana tvaṃ, gahapati, uttāno sattamāse nipajjitun”ti?
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.5.eng: “Are you able to lie on your back for seven months?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.7.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco seṭṭhiṃ gahapatiṃ mañcake nipātetvā mañcake sambandhitvā sīsacchaviṃ uppāṭetvā sibbiniṃ vināmetvā dve pāṇake nīharitvā mahājanassa dassesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.7.eng: Jīvaka then had the merchant lie down on a bed. He bound him to the bed, removed some skin from his head, opened a suture in the skull, and removed two insects. He showed them to the crowd, saying,

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.8.pli: “passathayye, ime dve pāṇake, ekaṃ khuddakaṃ ekaṃ mahallakaṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.8.eng: “Sirs, look at these two insects, one small and one large.

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.10.eng: he would live for five days

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.12.pli: Pañcamaṃ divasaṃ seṭṭhissa gahapatissa matthaluṅgaṃ pariyādiyissati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.12.eng: In five days it would have destroyed the merchant’s brain.

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.13.pli: Matthaluṅgassa pariyādānā seṭṭhi gahapati kālaṃ karissati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.13.eng: Because of that he would have died.

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.16.eng: he would live for seven days

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.18.pli: Sattamaṃ divasaṃ seṭṭhissa gahapatissa matthaluṅgaṃ pariyādiyissati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.18.eng: In seven days it would have destroyed the merchant’s brain.

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.19.pli: Matthaluṅgassa pariyādānā seṭṭhi gahapati kālaṃ karissati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.19.eng: Because of that he would have died.

pli-tv-kd8:1.18.21.pli: Sibbiniṃ sampaṭipāṭetvā sīsacchaviṃ sibbitvā ālepaṃ adāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.18.21.eng: He then closed the suture in the skull, sewed the skin back together, and applied an ointment.

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.1.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhi gahapati sattāhassa accayena jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.1.eng: After seven days the merchant said to Jīvaka,

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.2.pli: “nāhaṃ, ācariya, sakkomi ekena passena sattamāse nipajjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.2.eng: “Doctor, I’m unable to lie on one side for seven months.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.4.pli: sakkomahaṃ, ācariya, ekena passena sattamāse nipajjitun”ti?

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.5.pli: “Saccāhaṃ, ācariya, paṭissuṇiṃ, apāhaṃ marissāmi, nāhaṃ sakkomi ekena passena sattamāse nipajjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.5.eng: “I did, but I’ll die. I’m unable to do it.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.6.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, gahapati, dutiyena passena sattamāse nipajjāhī”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.6.eng: “Well then, lie on the other side for seven months.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.7.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhi gahapati sattāhassa accayena jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.7.eng: After seven days the merchant said to Jīvaka,

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.8.pli: “nāhaṃ, ācariya, sakkomi dutiyena passena sattamāse nipajjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.8.eng: “Doctor, I’m unable to lie on the other side for seven months.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.10.pli: sakkomahaṃ, ācariya, dutiyena passena sattamāse nipajjitun”ti?

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.11.pli: “Saccāhaṃ, ācariya, paṭissuṇiṃ, apāhaṃ marissāmi, nāhaṃ, ācariya, sakkomi dutiyena passena sattamāse nipajjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.11.eng: “I did, but I’ll die. I’m unable to do it.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.12.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, gahapati, uttāno sattamāse nipajjāhī”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.12.eng: “Well then, lie on your back for seven months.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.13.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhi gahapati sattāhassa accayena jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.13.eng: After seven days the merchant said to Jīvaka,

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.14.eng: “Doctor, I’m unable to lie on my back for seven months.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.19.17.pli: “Saccāhaṃ, ācariya, paṭissuṇiṃ, apāhaṃ marissāmi, nāhaṃ sakkomi uttāno sattamāse nipajjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.19.17.eng: “I did, but I’ll die. I’m unable to do it.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.20.1.pli: “Ahañce taṃ, gahapati, na vadeyyaṃ, ettakampi tvaṃ na nipajjeyyāsi, api ca paṭikacceva mayā ñāto—
pli-tv-kd8:1.20.1.eng: “If I hadn’t said this to you, you wouldn’t have been able to lie down for so long.

pli-tv-kd8:1.20.2.pli: tīhi sattāhehi seṭṭhi gahapati arogo bhavissatīti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.20.2.eng: I already knew that you would be well in three times seven days.

pli-tv-kd8:1.20.4.eng: But do you remember my fee?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.20.5.pli: “Sabbaṃ sāpateyyañca te, ācariya, hotu, ahañca te dāso”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.20.5.eng: “All my wealth is yours, doctor, and I’m your slave.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.20.6.pli: “Alaṃ, gahapati, mā me tvaṃ sabbaṃ sāpateyyaṃ adāsi, mā ca me dāso.

pli-tv-kd8:1.20.7.eng: Just give one hundred thousand coins to the king and another one hundred thousand to me.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.20.8.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhi gahapati arogo samāno rañño satasahassaṃ adāsi, jīvakassa komārabhaccassa satasahassaṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.20.8.eng: And being well, he did just that.

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.0.eng: 5. The account of the wealthy merchant’s son

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bārāṇaseyyakassa seṭṭhiputtassa mokkhacikāya kīḷantassa antagaṇṭhābādho hoti, yena yāgupi pītā na sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, bhattampi bhuttaṃ na sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, uccāropi passāvopi na paguṇo.
pli-tv-kd8:1.21.1.eng: On one occasion the son of a wealthy merchant in Benares twisted his gut while turning somersaults. Because of that, he was not able to digest congee or food, and he couldn’t urinate or defecate.

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.2.pli: So tena kiso hoti lūkho dubbaṇṇo uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāto dhamanisanthatagatto.
pli-tv-kd8:1.21.2.eng: He became thin, haggard, and pale, with veins protruding all over his body.

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.4.pli: “mayhaṃ kho puttassa tādiso ābādho, yena yāgupi pītā na sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, bhattampi bhuttaṃ na sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, uccāropi passāvopi na paguṇo.

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.5.pli: So tena kiso lūkho dubbaṇṇo uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāto dhamanisanthatagatto.

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ rājagahaṃ gantvā rājānaṃ jīvakaṃ vejjaṃ yāceyyaṃ puttaṃ me tikicchitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.21.6.eng: and thought, “Why don’t I go to Rājagaha and ask the king for doctor Jīvaka to treat my son?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.7.pli: Atha kho bārāṇaseyyako seṭṭhi rājagahaṃ gantvā yena rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ seniyaṃ bimbisāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.21.7.eng: He then traveled to Rājagaha, went to King Bimbisāra, and told him about his son,

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.8.pli: “mayhaṃ kho, deva, puttassa tādiso ābādho, yena yāgupi pītā na sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, bhattampi bhuttaṃ na sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, uccāropi passāvopi na paguṇo.

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.9.pli: So tena kiso lūkho dubbaṇṇo uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāto dhamanisanthatagatto.

pli-tv-kd8:1.21.10.pli: Sādhu devo jīvakaṃ vejjaṃ āṇāpetu puttaṃ me tikicchitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.21.10.eng: adding, “Sir, please ask doctor Jīvaka to treat my son.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.22.1.eng: And that’s what the king did.

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.2.pli: “gaccha, bhaṇe jīvaka, bārāṇasiṃ gantvā bārāṇaseyyakaṃ seṭṭhiputtaṃ tikicchāhī”ti.

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.3.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa paṭissutvā bārāṇasiṃ gantvā yena bārāṇaseyyako seṭṭhiputto tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bārāṇaseyyakassa seṭṭhiputtassa vikāraṃ sallakkhetvā janaṃ ussāretvā tirokaraṇiyaṃ parikkhipitvā thambhe ubbandhitvā bhariyaṃ purato ṭhapetvā udaracchaviṃ uppāṭetvā antagaṇṭhiṃ nīharitvā bhariyāya dassesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.22.3.eng: Jīvaka consented and then traveled to Benares where he went to that merchant. He examined his son, dismissed the people there, put up a curtain all around, and tied him to a pillar. He then had his wife stand in front of him, cut open his belly, and pulled out his twisted gut. He showed it to his wife, saying,

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.4.pli: “passa te sāmikassa ābādhaṃ, iminā yāgupi pītā na sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, bhattampi bhuttaṃ na sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, uccāropi passāvopi na paguṇo;

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.5.pli: imināyaṃ kiso lūkho dubbaṇṇo uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāto dhamanisanthatagatto”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.22.5.eng: It’s because of this that he’s in such a bad state.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.6.pli: Antagaṇṭhiṃ viniveṭhetvā antāni paṭipavesetvā udaracchaviṃ sibbitvā ālepaṃ adāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.22.6.eng: He then untwisted the gut, put it back, sewed his belly back together, and applied ointment.

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.7.pli: Atha kho bārāṇaseyyako seṭṭhiputto nacirasseva arogo ahosi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.22.7.eng: Soon the merchant’s son was healthy again.

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.9.pli: “putto me arogo ṭhito”ti jīvakassa komārabhaccassa soḷasasahassāni pādāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.22.9.eng: His father gave sixteen thousand coins to Jīvaka,

pli-tv-kd8:1.22.10.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco tāni soḷasasahassāni ādāya punadeva rājagahaṃ paccāgañchi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.23.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pajjotassa paṇḍurogābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.23.1.eng: At that time King Pajjota had jaundice.

pli-tv-kd8:1.23.2.pli: Bahū mahantā mahantā disāpāmokkhā vejjā āgantvā nāsakkhiṃsu arogaṃ kātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.23.2.eng: Many of the most famous physicians in the world had come to see him, but none was able to cure him.

pli-tv-kd8:1.23.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pajjoto rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa santike dūtaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.23.4.eng: King Pajjota then sent a message to King Bimbisāra:

pli-tv-kd8:1.23.5.pli: “mayhaṃ kho tādiso ābādho, sādhu devo jīvakaṃ vejjaṃ āṇāpetu, so maṃ tikicchissatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.23.5.eng: “Sir, I have such-and-such a disease. Please ask doctor Jīvaka to treat me.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.23.6.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ āṇāpesi—

pli-tv-kd8:1.23.9.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa paṭissutvā ujjeniṃ gantvā yena rājā pajjoto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rañño pajjotassa vikāraṃ sallakkhetvā rājānaṃ pajjotaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.23.9.eng: Jīvaka consented and traveled to Ujjenī. He then went to King Pajjota, examined him, and said,

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.2.eng: I’ll make a medicine from it for you to drink.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.3.pli: “Alaṃ, bhaṇe jīvaka, yaṃ te sakkā vinā sappinā arogaṃ kātuṃ taṃ karohi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.24.3.eng: “Forget it, Jīvaka. Make whatever will cure me that doesn’t contain ghee.

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.6.pli: “imassa kho rañño tādiso ābādho, na sakkā vinā sappinā arogaṃ kātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.24.6.eng: “I won’t be able to cure this sickness without ghee.

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ sappiṃ nippaceyyaṃ kasāvavaṇṇaṃ kasāvagandhaṃ kasāvarasan”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.24.7.eng: Why don’t I prepare medicine from ghee, but with a bitter color, smell, and taste?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.8.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco nānābhesajjehi sappiṃ nippaci kasāvavaṇṇaṃ kasāvagandhaṃ kasāvarasaṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.24.8.eng: Jīvaka then cooked ghee with a number of medicines, but he made sure it had the color, smell, and taste of a bitter substance.

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.10.pli: “imassa kho rañño sappi pītaṃ pariṇāmentaṃ uddekaṃ dassati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.24.10.eng: “When the king is digesting the ghee after drinking it, it will make him vomit.

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.11.eng: And because he’s temperamental, he might have me executed.

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.12.eng: Let me take leave in advance.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.24.13.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco yena rājā pajjoto tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ pajjotaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.24.13.eng: He then went to the king and said,

pli-tv-kd8:1.25.1.pli: “mayaṃ kho, deva, vejjā nāma tādisena muhuttena mūlāni uddharāma bhesajjāni saṃharāma.
pli-tv-kd8:1.25.1.eng: “Sir, we doctors need to pull up roots and collect medicines at short notice.

pli-tv-kd8:1.25.2.pli: Sādhu devo vāhanāgāresu ca dvāresu ca āṇāpetu—
pli-tv-kd8:1.25.2.eng: Please instruct the stables and the gates:

pli-tv-kd8:1.25.3.pli: yena vāhanena jīvako icchati tena vāhanena gacchatu, yena dvārena icchati tena dvārena gacchatu, yaṃ kālaṃ icchati taṃ kālaṃ gacchatu, yaṃ kālaṃ icchati taṃ kālaṃ pavisatū”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.25.3.eng: ‘Jīvaka may ride on whatever animal he wishes, depart by whatever gate he desires, and he may come and go as he pleases.’”

pli-tv-kd8:1.25.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pajjoto vāhanāgāresu ca dvāresu ca āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.25.4.eng: The king did as Jīvaka had asked.

pli-tv-kd8:1.25.5.pli: “yena vāhanena jīvako icchati tena vāhanena gacchatu, yena dvārena icchati tena dvārena gacchatu, yaṃ kālaṃ icchati taṃ kālaṃ gacchatu, yaṃ kālaṃ icchati taṃ kālaṃ pavisatū”ti.

pli-tv-kd8:1.25.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pajjotassa bhaddavatikā nāma hatthinikā paññāsayojanikā hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.25.6.eng: At that time King Pajjota had a she-elephant called Bhaddavatikā, which could traverse 650 kilometers in a day.

pli-tv-kd8:1.25.7.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño pajjotassa sappiṃ upanāmesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.25.7.eng: After bringing the ghee to the king

pli-tv-kd8:1.25.9.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco rājānaṃ pajjotaṃ sappiṃ pāyetvā hatthisālaṃ gantvā bhaddavatikāya hatthinikāya nagaramhā nippati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.25.9.eng: and having him drink it, Jīvaka went to the elephant stables and fled the city on Bhaddavatikā.

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.1.pli: Atha kho rañño pajjotassa taṃ sappi pītaṃ pariṇāmentaṃ uddekaṃ adāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.26.1.eng: Soon afterwards, while King Pajjota was digesting that ghee, he vomited.

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pajjoto manusse etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.3.eng: “That scoundrel Jīvaka made me drink ghee.

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.4.pli: Tena hi, bhaṇe, jīvakaṃ vejjaṃ vicinathā”ti.

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.5.eng: “Sir, he’s fled the city on Bhaddavatikā.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pajjotassa kāko nāma dāso saṭṭhiyojaniko hoti, amanussena paṭicca jāto.
pli-tv-kd8:1.26.6.eng: At that time King Pajjota had a slave called Kāka, whose mother was a spirit and who could traverse 780 kilometers in a day.

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.7.pli: Atha kho rājā pajjoto kākaṃ dāsaṃ āṇāpesi—

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.8.eng: “Go, Kāka, and make Jīvaka turn back.

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.9.eng: Tell him that the king is asking him to return.

pli-tv-kd8:1.26.10.pli: Ete kho, bhaṇe kāka, vejjā nāma bahumāyā.
pli-tv-kd8:1.26.10.eng: But Kāka, these doctors are full of tricks.

pli-tv-kd8:1.27.1.pli: Atha kho kāko dāso jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ antarāmagge kosambiyaṃ sambhāvesi pātarāsaṃ karontaṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:1.27.1.eng: Kāka caught up with Jīvaka at Kosambī, while he was still on his way and having breakfast.

pli-tv-kd8:1.27.2.pli: Atha kho kāko dāso jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd8:1.27.3.eng: “Doctor, the king is asking you to return.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.27.5.eng: Why don’t you have something too?”

pli-tv-kd8:1.27.7.pli: ete kho, bhaṇe kāka, vejjā nāma bahumāyā, mā cassa kiñci paṭiggahesī”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.27.7.eng: The king told me that doctors are full of tricks and that I shouldn’t receive anything from you.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.27.8.pli: Tena kho pana samayena jīvako komārabhacco nakhena bhesajjaṃ olumpetvā āmalakañca khādati pānīyañca pivati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.27.8.eng: Jīvaka then removed the medicinal part of an emblic myrobalan fruit with his nail, before eating it and drinking water.

pli-tv-kd8:1.27.9.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco kākaṃ dāsaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd8:1.27.10.pli: “handa, bhaṇe kāka, āmalakañca khāda pānīyañca pivassū”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.27.10.eng: “Here, Kāka, have some emblic myrobalan and water.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho vejjo āmalakañca khādati pānīyañca pivati, na arahati kiñci pāpakaṃ hotun”ti—
pli-tv-kd8:1.28.2.eng: “The doctor is eating and drinking it. It can’t be anything bad.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.3.eng: So he ate half a fruit and drank the water.

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.4.pli: Tassa taṃ upaḍḍhāmalakaṃ khāditaṃ tattheva nicchāresi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.28.4.eng: When he had eaten it, he vomited right there.

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.5.pli: Atha kho kāko dāso jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.7.pli: “Mā, bhaṇe kāka, bhāyi, tvañceva arogo bhavissasi rājā ca.
pli-tv-kd8:1.28.7.eng: “Don’t be afraid, Kāka. Both you and the king will be well.

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.8.pli: Caṇḍo so rājā ghātāpeyyāpi maṃ, tenāhaṃ na nivattāmī”ti
pli-tv-kd8:1.28.8.eng: But the king is temperamental and might have me executed. Because of that I won’t return.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.9.pli: bhaddavatikaṃ hatthinikaṃ kākassa niyyādetvā yena rājagahaṃ tena pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.28.9.eng: After handing back the she-elephant Bhaddavatikā to Kāka, he continued on to Rājagaha.

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.10.pli: Anupubbena yena rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.28.10.eng: When he eventually arrived, he went to King Bimbisāra and told him what had happened.

pli-tv-kd8:1.28.11.pli: “Suṭṭhu, bhaṇe jīvaka, akāsi yampi na nivatto, caṇḍo so rājā ghātāpeyyāpi tan”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.28.11.eng: The king said, “It’s good, Jīvaka, that you didn’t return. That king is temperamental and might even have had you executed.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pajjoto arogo samāno jīvakassa komārabhaccassa santike dūtaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.29.1.eng: When King Pajjota was cured, he sent a message to Jīvaka:

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.2.eng: “Come, Jīvaka, I wish to give you a gift.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.3.eng: He replied, “There’s no need, sir. Please just remember my act of service.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.4.0.eng: 7. The account of the two valuable cloths

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pajjotassa siveyyakaṃ dussayugaṃ uppannaṃ hoti—
pli-tv-kd8:1.29.4.1.eng: Soon afterwards King Pajjota obtained two valuable cloths.

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.5.pli: bahūnaṃ dussānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasatānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasahassānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasatasahassānaṃ aggañca seṭṭhañca mokkhañca uttamañca pavarañca.
pli-tv-kd8:1.29.5.eng: They were extremely exquisite and fine, one in a million.

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.6.pli: Atha kho rājā pajjoto taṃ siveyyakaṃ dussayugaṃ jīvakassa komārabhaccassa pāhesi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.29.6.eng: The king sent them to Jīvaka.

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.8.pli: “idaṃ kho me siveyyakaṃ dussayugaṃ raññā pajjotena pahitaṃ—

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.9.pli: bahūnaṃ dussānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasatānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasahassānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasatasahassānaṃ aggañca seṭṭhañca mokkhañca uttamañca pavarañca.

pli-tv-kd8:1.29.10.pli: Nayidaṃ añño koci paccārahati aññatra tena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena, raññā vā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārenā”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.29.10.eng: “No-one is worthy of these except the Buddha, the Perfected and fully Awakened One, or King Bimbisāra.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.30.0.eng: 8. The account of the thirty purgings

pli-tv-kd8:1.30.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavato kāyo dosābhisanno hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.30.1.eng: On one occasion the Buddha’s body was full of impurities.

pli-tv-kd8:1.30.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi—

pli-tv-kd8:1.30.3.eng: “Ānanda, my body is full of impurities.

pli-tv-kd8:1.30.4.eng: I would like to take a purgative.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.30.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena jīvako komārabhacco tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.30.5.eng: Ānanda went to Jīvaka and told him what the Buddha had said.

pli-tv-kd8:1.30.8.pli: “Tena hi, bhante ānanda, bhagavato kāyaṃ katipāhaṃ sinehethā”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.30.8.eng: And Jīvaka replied, “Well then, Venerable Ānanda, oil the Buddha’s body for a few days.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.30.9.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato kāyaṃ katipāhaṃ sinehetvā yena jīvako komārabhacco tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:1.30.9.eng: After doing as instructed, Ānanda returned to Jīvaka to let him know, adding,

pli-tv-kd8:1.31.2.pli: “na kho metaṃ patirūpaṃ yohaṃ bhagavato oḷārikaṃ virecanaṃ dadeyyan”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.31.2.eng: “It would not be appropriate for me to give the Buddha a powerful purgative.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.31.3.pli: Tīṇi uppalahatthāni nānābhesajjehi paribhāvetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃ uppalahatthaṃ bhagavato upanāmesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.31.3.eng: He then prepared three handfuls of lotus flowers with a variety of medicines, went to the Buddha, and gave him one handful, saying,

pli-tv-kd8:1.31.5.eng: This will purge you ten times.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.31.6.eng: He then brought him the second

pli-tv-kd8:1.31.9.eng: and the third handful, repeating the instruction,

pli-tv-kd8:1.31.12.eng: adding, “In this way you’ll have thirty purgings.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.31.13.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavato samattiṃsāya virecanaṃ datvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.31.13.eng: After giving the Buddha thirty purgings, he bowed down, circumambulated him with his right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.1.pli: Atha kho jīvakassa komārabhaccassa bahi dvārakoṭṭhakā nikkhantassa etadahosi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.32.1.eng: When he was outside the gatehouse, Jīvaka thought,

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.2.eng: “I’ve given thirty purgings to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.3.eng: for his body is full of impurities.

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.4.pli: Na bhagavantaṃ samattiṃsakkhattuṃ virecessati, ekūnattiṃsakkhattuṃ bhagavantaṃ virecessati.
pli-tv-kd8:1.32.4.eng: But he’ll only be purged twenty-nine times.

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.5.eng: After being purged, however, he’ll take a bath,

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.6.eng: which will count as one purging.

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.7.eng: In this way the Buddha will have had exactly thirty purgings.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.8.pli: Atha kho bhagavā jīvakassa komārabhaccassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.32.8.eng: The Buddha read Jīvaka’s mind. He told Ānanda about it,

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.9.pli: “idhānanda, jīvakassa komārabhaccassa bahi dvārakoṭṭhakā nikkhantassa etadahosi—

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.12.pli: Na bhagavantaṃ samatiṃsakkhattuṃ virecessati, ekūnattiṃsakkhattuṃ bhagavantaṃ virecessati.

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.16.eng: adding, “Well then, Ānanda, prepare hot water,”

pli-tv-kd8:1.32.17.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissuṇitvā uṇhodakaṃ paṭiyādesi.

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.1.eng: Jīvaka then went back to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.5.pli: “Idha mayhaṃ, bhante, bahi dvārakoṭṭhakā nikkhantassa etadahosi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.5.eng: Jīvaka told him what he had thought outside the gatehouse,

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.8.pli: Na bhagavantaṃ samattiṃsakkhattuṃ virecessati, ekūnattiṃsakkhattuṃ bhagavantaṃ virecessati.

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.13.eng: The Buddha had a hot bath.

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.14.eng: When he had bathed, the Buddha was purged once,

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.15.eng: adding up to a total of thirty purgings.

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.16.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.17.pli: “yāva, bhante, bhagavato kāyo pakatatto hoti, alaṃ yūsapiṇḍapātenā”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.17.eng: “Sir, until your body is back to normal, please don’t take any mung-bean broth.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.18.0.eng: 9. The account of asking for a favor

pli-tv-kd8:1.33.18.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavato kāyo nacirasseva pakatatto ahosi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.18.1.eng: Soon the Buddha’s body was back to normal.

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.1.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco taṃ siveyyakaṃ dussayugaṃ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.1.eng: Jīvaka then took those two valuable cloths and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.3.eng: “Sir, I wish to ask for a favor.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.7.eng: “The Buddha and the Sangha of monks are rag-robe wearers.

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.8.pli: Idaṃ me, bhante, siveyyakaṃ dussayugaṃ raññā pajjotena pahitaṃ—
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.8.eng: But I’ve received these two valuable cloths from King Pajjota

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.9.pli: bahūnaṃ dussānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasatānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasahassānaṃ bahūnaṃ dussayugasatasahassānaṃ aggañca seṭṭhañca mokkhañca uttamañca pavarañca.
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.9.eng: that are extremely exquisite and fine—they are one in a million.

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.10.pli: Paṭiggaṇhātu me, bhante, bhagavā siveyyakaṃ dussayugaṃ;

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.11.eng: and please allow the Sangha of monks to use robe-cloth given by householders.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.12.eng: The Buddha received the two valuable cloths.

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.13.pli: Atha kho bhagavā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.13.eng: He then instructed, inspired, and gladdened Jīvaka with a teaching,

pli-tv-kd8:1.34.14.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.14.eng: after which Jīvaka got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd8:1.35.1.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.2.eng: “Monks, I allow you to use robe-cloth given by householders.

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.3.eng: Anyone who wishes may wear rag-robes

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.4.eng: and anyone who wishes may accept robe-cloth from householders.

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.5.eng: But I praise contentment with one or the other.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.7.eng: that the Buddha had allowed the monks to use robe-cloth given by householders.

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.8.pli: Te ca manussā haṭṭhā ahesuṃ udaggā—
pli-tv-kd8:1.35.8.eng: They were excited and joyful, thinking,

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.9.pli: “idāni kho mayaṃ dānāni dassāma puññāni karissāma, yato bhagavatā bhikkhūnaṃ gahapaticīvaraṃ anuññātan”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.35.9.eng: “Now we’ll give gifts and make merit.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.10.eng: In just a single day many thousands of robes were given at Rājagaha.

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.11.eng: And the same thing happened in the country.

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.13.pli: Te ca manussā haṭṭhā ahesuṃ udaggā—

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.14.pli: “idāni kho mayaṃ dānāni dassāma puññāni karissāma, yato bhagavatā bhikkhūnaṃ gahapaticīvaraṃ anuññātan”ti.

pli-tv-kd8:1.36.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa pāvāro uppanno hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:1.36.1.eng: At that time, a fleecy robe was offered to the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd8:1.36.1.comm: “Was offered” renders uppanna. This word, which literally means “arisen”, varies slightly in meaning dependent on the context. Often it refers to a requisite that has just been given to the Sangha or an individual monastic. Occasionally however, such as here, this does not fit the context. Here we need to assume that the monks had not yet received it, seeing as they ask the Buddha whether or not the robe is allowable. In other words, here uppanna happens first, and only then is the robe given. The meaning, then, must be that the monks had been given an offer or a promise of this robe, but had not yet received it. In a sense, the robe had “become available” to them. The most common way for a requisite to become available to a monastic is that an offer is made. I translate accordingly. See also DOP for this meaning of uppanna.

pli-tv-kd8:1.36.3.comm: Sp 3.337: Pāvāroti salomako kappāsādibhedo, “Pāvāra means cotton, etc., with hair.” Sp-yoj 3.337: Pāvāroti uttarāsaṅgo, “Pāvāro means upper robe.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.36.4.eng: And a silken, fleecy robe was offered.

pli-tv-kd8:1.36.7.eng: And a woolen, fleecy robe was offered.

pli-tv-kd8:1.36.9.comm: Vin-ālaṅ-ṭ 34.57: Kojavanti uṇṇāmayo pāvārasadiso, “Kojava is like a pāvāra made of wool.”

pli-tv-kd8:1.36.10.eng: The first section for recitation is finished.

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.0.eng: 10. Discussion on the allowance of wool

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kāsirājā jīvakassa komārabhaccassa aḍḍhakāsikaṃ kambalaṃ pāhesi upaḍḍhakāsinaṃ khamamānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.1.eng: On one occasion the king of Kāsi sent a valuable, woolen Kāsi cloth to Jīvaka.

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.2.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco taṃ aḍḍhakāsikaṃ kambalaṃ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.2.eng: Jīvaka took the cloth and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.3.eng: and told him what had happened,

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.4.pli: “ayaṃ me, bhante, aḍḍhakāsiko kambalo kāsiraññā pahito upaḍḍhakāsinaṃ khamamāno.

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.5.pli: Paṭiggaṇhātu me, bhante, bhagavā kambalaṃ, yaṃ mamassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.5.eng: adding, “Sir, please accept this woolen cloth for my long-lasting benefit and happiness.”

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.6.eng: The Buddha received the woolen cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi …pe…
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.7.eng: He then instructed, inspired, and gladdened Jīvaka with a teaching,

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.8.eng: after which Jīvaka got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.9.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.9.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd8:2.1.10.comm: In connection with Bu Np 26:1.23.1, which concerns thread used for weaving robes, Sp 1.636 says: Kambalanti eḷakalomasuttaṁ, “Kambala means a thread of wool.”

pli-tv-kd8:3.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa uccāvacāni cīvarāni uppannāni honti.
pli-tv-kd8:3.1.1.eng: At that time various kinds of robe-cloth were offered to the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd8:3.1.1.comm: “Robe-cloth” renders cīvara. See Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd8:3.1.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho bhagavatā cīvaraṃ anuññātaṃ, kiṃ ananuññātan”ti?
pli-tv-kd8:3.1.3.eng: “What kind of robe-cloth has and hasn’t the Buddha allowed?”

pli-tv-kd8:3.1.6.pli: khomaṃ kappāsikaṃ koseyyaṃ kambalaṃ sāṇaṃ bhaṅgan”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:3.1.6.eng: linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp.”
pli-tv-kd8:3.1.6.comm: “Cotton” renders kappāsika, “sunn hemp” sāṇa, and “hemp” bhaṅga. See Appendix of Plants.

pli-tv-kd8:3.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena ye te bhikkhū gahapaticīvaraṃ sādiyanti te kukkuccāyantā paṃsukūlaṃ na sādiyanti—
pli-tv-kd8:3.2.1.eng: Soon afterwards the monks thought, “The Buddha has only allowed one kind of robe, not two,”

pli-tv-kd8:3.2.2.eng: and being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not accept rags after receiving robe-cloth from householders.

pli-tv-kd8:3.2.4.eng: “I allow you to accept rags after receiving robe-cloth from a householder.

pli-tv-kd8:3.2.5.eng: But I praise contentment with both.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū kosalesu janapade addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti.
pli-tv-kd8:4.1.1.eng: On one occasion when a number of monks were traveling through the Kosalan country,

pli-tv-kd8:4.1.2.pli: Ekacce bhikkhū susānaṃ okkamiṃsu paṃsukūlāya, ekacce bhikkhū nāgamesuṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:4.1.2.eng: some of them entered a charnel ground to look for rags, while the others walked on.

pli-tv-kd8:4.1.3.pli: Ye te bhikkhū susānaṃ okkamiṃsu paṃsukūlāya te paṃsukūlāni labhiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd8:4.1.3.eng: The former monks got hold of rags,

pli-tv-kd8:4.1.4.pli: Ye te bhikkhū nāgamesuṃ te evamāhaṃsu—

pli-tv-kd8:4.1.8.eng: We won’t give you a share.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.1.10.eng: “If you’re unwilling, you don’t have to give a share to those who don’t wait.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū kosalesu janapade addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti.
pli-tv-kd8:4.2.1.eng: On another occasion when a number of monks were traveling through the Kosalan country,

pli-tv-kd8:4.2.2.pli: Ekacce bhikkhū susānaṃ okkamiṃsu paṃsukūlāya, ekacce bhikkhū āgamesuṃ.
pli-tv-kd8:4.2.2.eng: some of them entered a charnel ground to look for rags, while the others waited.

pli-tv-kd8:4.2.3.pli: Ye te bhikkhū susānaṃ okkamiṃsu paṃsukūlāya te paṃsukūlāni labhiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd8:4.2.3.eng: The former monks got hold of rags,

pli-tv-kd8:4.2.4.pli: Ye te bhikkhū āgamesuṃ te evamāhaṃsu—

pli-tv-kd8:4.2.7.eng: “But why didn’t you come with us, then?

pli-tv-kd8:4.2.8.eng: We won’t give you a share.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.2.10.eng: “Even if you’re unwilling, you should give a share to those who wait.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū kosalesu janapade addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti.
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.1.eng: On yet another occasion when a number of monks were traveling through the Kosalan country,

pli-tv-kd8:4.3.2.pli: Ekacce bhikkhū paṭhamaṃ susānaṃ okkamiṃsu paṃsukūlāya, ekacce bhikkhū pacchā okkamiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.2.eng: some of them entered a charnel ground to look for rags first, while the other monks entered afterwards.

pli-tv-kd8:4.3.3.pli: Ye te bhikkhū paṭhamaṃ susānaṃ okkamiṃsu paṃsukūlāya te paṃsukūlāni labhiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.3.eng: Those who entered first got hold of rags,

pli-tv-kd8:4.3.4.pli: Ye te bhikkhū pacchā okkamiṃsu te na labhiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.4.eng: but not those who entered afterwards.

pli-tv-kd8:4.3.8.eng: “But why did you come in afterwards, then?

pli-tv-kd8:4.3.9.eng: We won’t give you a share.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.3.11.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pacchā okkantānaṃ nākāmā bhāgaṃ dātun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.11.eng: “If you’re unwilling, you don’t have to give a share to those who enter afterwards.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū kosalesu janapade addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti.
pli-tv-kd8:4.4.1.eng: On yet another occasion when a number of monks were traveling through the Kosalan country,

pli-tv-kd8:4.4.2.eng: they all entered a charnel ground together to look for rags.
pli-tv-kd8:4.4.2.comm: Sp 3.340: Sadisā susānaṁ okkamiṁsūti sabbe samaṁ okkamiṁsu, “Sadisā susānaṁ okkamiṁsu: they all entered together.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.4.3.pli: Ekacce bhikkhū paṃsukūlāni labhiṃsu, ekacce bhikkhū na labhiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd8:4.4.3.eng: Some of them got hold of rags, while others did not.

pli-tv-kd8:4.4.4.pli: Ye te bhikkhū na labhiṃsu, te evamāhaṃsu—

pli-tv-kd8:4.4.8.eng: We won’t give you a share.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.4.10.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, sadisānaṃ okkantānaṃ akāmā bhāgaṃ dātun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:4.4.10.eng: “Even if you’re unwilling, you should give a share to those who enter together with you.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū kosalesu janapade addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti.
pli-tv-kd8:4.5.1.eng: On yet another occasion when a number of monks were traveling through the Kosalan country,

pli-tv-kd8:4.5.2.pli: Te katikaṃ katvā susānaṃ okkamiṃsu paṃsukūlāya.
pli-tv-kd8:4.5.2.eng: they entered a charnel ground together to look for rags after making an agreement to share.
pli-tv-kd8:4.5.2.comm: Sp 3.340: Te katikaṁ katvāti laddhaṁ paṁsukūlaṁ sabbe bhājetvā gaṇhissāmāti bahimeva katikaṁ katvā, “After making an agreement about it means: having made an agreement outside, as follows: ‘We will get (rags) by distributing the obtained rags to everyone.’”

pli-tv-kd8:4.5.3.pli: Ekacce bhikkhū paṃsukūlāni labhiṃsu, ekacce bhikkhū na labhiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd8:4.5.3.eng: Some of them got hold of rags, while others did not.

pli-tv-kd8:4.5.4.pli: Ye te bhikkhū na labhiṃsu te evamāhaṃsu—

pli-tv-kd8:4.5.8.eng: We won’t give you a share.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.5.10.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, katikaṃ katvā okkantānaṃ akāmā bhāgaṃ dātun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:4.5.10.eng: “Even if you’re unwilling, if you have made an agreement about it, you should give a share to those who enter.”

pli-tv-kd8:5.1.0.eng: 12. Discussion on the appointment of a receiver of robe-cloth

pli-tv-kd8:5.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena manussā cīvaraṃ ādāya ārāmaṃ āgacchanti.
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.1.eng: At that time people brought robe-cloth to the monastery,

pli-tv-kd8:5.1.2.eng: but not finding anyone to receive it, they took it back.

pli-tv-kd8:5.1.3.eng: As a result, only a little robe-cloth was given at that monastery.

pli-tv-kd8:5.1.5.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgataṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvarapaṭiggāhakaṃ sammannituṃ—
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.5.eng: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the receiver of robe-cloth:

pli-tv-kd8:5.1.6.pli: yo na chandāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na dosāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na mohāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na bhayāgatiṃ gaccheyya, gahitāgahitañca jāneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.6.eng: he’s not biased by favoritism, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what has and what hasn’t been received.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.1.eng: And this is how he should be appointed.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.2.eng: First a monk should be asked,

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.3.pli: yācitvā byattena bhikkhunā paṭibalena saṅgho ñāpetabbo—
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.3.eng: and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.4.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.5.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ saṅgho itthannāmaṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvarapaṭiggāhakaṃ sammanneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.5.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should appoint monk so-and-so as the receiver of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.7.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.8.eng: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the receiver of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.9.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa bhikkhuno cīvarapaṭiggāhakassa sammuti, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.9.eng: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the receiver of robe-cloth should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.10.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.11.eng: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the receiver of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:5.2.12.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.12.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd8:6.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena cīvarapaṭiggāhakā bhikkhū cīvaraṃ paṭiggahetvā tattheva ujjhitvā pakkamanti.
pli-tv-kd8:6.1.1.eng: Soon, after receiving cloth, the receivers of robe-cloth left it right there and went away.

pli-tv-kd8:6.1.4.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgataṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvaranidahakaṃ sammannituṃ—
pli-tv-kd8:6.1.4.eng: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the keeper of robe-cloth:

pli-tv-kd8:6.1.5.pli: yo na chandāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na dosāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na mohāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na bhayāgatiṃ gaccheyya, nihitānihitañca jāneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:6.1.5.eng: he’s not biased by favoritism, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what is and what isn’t stored.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.1.eng: And this is how he should be appointed.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.2.eng: First a monk should be asked,

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.3.pli: yācitvā byattena bhikkhunā paṭibalena saṅgho ñāpetabbo—
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.3.eng: and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.4.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.5.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho itthannāmaṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvaranidahakaṃ sammanneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.5.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should appoint monk so-and-so as the keeper of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.7.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.8.eng: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the keeper of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.9.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa bhikkhuno cīvaranidahakassa sammuti, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.9.eng: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the keeper of robe-cloth should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.10.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.11.eng: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the keeper of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:6.2.12.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.12.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd8:7.1.0.eng: 13. Discussion on the designation of a storeroom, etc.

pli-tv-kd8:7.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena cīvaranidahako bhikkhu maṇḍapepi rukkhamūlepi nibbakosepi cīvaraṃ nidahati, undūrehipi upacikāhipi khajjanti.
pli-tv-kd8:7.1.1.eng: Soon afterwards the monk who was the keeper of robe-cloth stored it under a roof cover, at the foot of a tree, and under the eaves of a building. Rats and termites ate it.

pli-tv-kd8:7.1.3.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, bhaṇḍāgāraṃ sammannituṃ, yaṃ saṅgho ākaṅkhati vihāraṃ vā aḍḍhayogaṃ vā pāsādaṃ vā hammiyaṃ vā guhaṃ vā.
pli-tv-kd8:7.1.3.eng: “I allow you to designate a dwelling, a stilt house, or a cave as a storeroom.
pli-tv-kd8:7.1.3.comm: Apart from the vihāra, “a dwelling”, and the guhā, “a cave”, the Pali mentions three kinds of buildings, the aḍḍhayoga, the pāsāda, and the hammiya, all of which, according to the commentaries, are different kinds of pāsāda, “stilt houses”. Rather than try to differentiate between these buildings, which is unlikely to be useful from a practical perspective, I have instead grouped them together as “stilt house”. Here is what the commentaries have to say. Sp 4.294: Aḍḍhayogoti supaṇṇavaṅkagehaṁ, “An aḍḍhayoga is a house bent like a supaṇṇa.” Sp-ṭ 4.294 clarifies: Supaṇṇavaṅkagehanti garuḷapakkhasaṇṭhānena katagehaṁ, “Supaṇṇavaṅkageha: a house made in the shape of the wings of a garuḷa.” A garuḷa, better known in its Sanskrit form garuḍa, is a mythological bird. Sp 4.294 continues: Pāsādoti dīghapāsādo. Hammiyanti upariākāsatale patiṭṭhitakūṭāgāro pāsādoyeva, “A pāsāda is a long stilt house. A hammiya is just a pāsāda that has an upper room on top of its flat roof.” At Sp-ṭ 3.74, however, we find slightly different explanations. It seems clear, however, that all three are stilt houses and that they are distinguished according to their shape and the kind of roof they possess.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.1.eng: And this is how it should be designated.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.2.eng: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.3.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.4.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho itthannāmaṃ vihāraṃ bhaṇḍāgāraṃ sammanneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.4.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should designate such-and-such a dwelling as a storeroom.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.6.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.7.eng: The Sangha designates such-and-such a dwelling as a storeroom.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.8.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa vihārassa bhaṇḍāgārassa sammuti, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.8.eng: Any monk who approves of designating such-and-such a dwelling as a storeroom should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.9.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.10.eng: The Sangha has designated such-and-such a dwelling as a storeroom.

pli-tv-kd8:7.2.11.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.11.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa bhaṇḍāgāre cīvaraṃ aguttaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.1.eng: Soon, the robe-cloth in the Sangha’s storeroom was not looked after.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.3.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgataṃ bhikkhuṃ bhaṇḍāgārikaṃ sammannituṃ—yo na chandāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na dosāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na mohāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na bhayāgatiṃ gaccheyya, guttāguttañca jāneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.3.eng: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the storeman: he’s not biased by favoritism, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what is and what isn’t protected.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.3.comm: Sp 3.343: Guttāguttañca jāneyyāti ettha yassa tāva chadanādīsu koci doso natthi, taṁ guttaṁ, “Guttāguttañca jāneyya: here, in so far as there is no fault in the roofing, etc., it is protected.” The commentary then goes on to say he should make repairs if the stored goods are unprotected.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.4.eng: And this is how he should be appointed.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.5.eng: First a monk should be asked,

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.6.pli: yācitvā byattena bhikkhunā paṭibalena saṅgho ñāpetabbo—
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.6.eng: and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.7.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.8.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho itthannāmaṃ bhikkhuṃ bhaṇḍāgārikaṃ sammanneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.8.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should appoint monk so-and-so as the storeman.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.10.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.11.eng: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the storeman.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.12.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa bhikkhuno bhaṇḍāgārikassa sammuti, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.12.eng: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the storeman should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.13.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.14.eng: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the storeman.

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.15.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.15.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd8:8.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū bhaṇḍāgārikaṃ vuṭṭhāpenti.
pli-tv-kd8:8.2.1.eng: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six dismissed the storeman.

pli-tv-kd8:8.2.4.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa bhaṇḍāgāre cīvaraṃ ussannaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.1.eng: At one time there was much robe-cloth in the Sangha’s storeroom.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅgho cīvaraṃ bhājento kolāhalaṃ akāsi.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.4.eng: Soon afterwards there was a racket as the Sangha was distributing that robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.6.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgataṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvarabhājakaṃ sammannituṃ—
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.6.eng: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the distributor of robe-cloth:

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.7.pli: yo na chandāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na dosāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na mohāgatiṃ gaccheyya, na bhayāgatiṃ gaccheyya, bhājitābhājitañca jāneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.7.eng: he’s not biased by favoritism, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what has and what has not been distributed.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.8.eng: And this is how he should be appointed.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.9.eng: First a monk should be asked,

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.10.pli: yācitvā byattena bhikkhunā paṭibalena saṅgho ñāpetabbo—
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.10.eng: and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.11.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.12.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho itthannāmaṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvarabhājakaṃ sammanneyya.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.12.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should appoint monk so-and-so as the distributor of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.14.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.15.eng: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the distributor of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.16.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa bhikkhuno cīvarabhājakassa sammuti, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.16.eng: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the distributor of robe-cloth should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.17.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.18.eng: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the distributor of robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.19.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.19.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd8:9.2.1.eng: The monks who were the distributors of robe-cloth thought,

pli-tv-kd8:9.2.4.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ uccinitvā tulayitvā vaṇṇāvaṇṇaṃ katvā bhikkhū gaṇetvā vaggaṃ bandhitvā cīvarapaṭivīsaṃ ṭhapetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:9.2.4.eng: “You should first sort the cloth, then estimate its value, followed by grouping it according to value, counting the monks, gathering the monks into groups, and finally fixing the shares of robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-kd8:9.2.4.comm: Sp 3.343: Uccinitvāti “‘idaṁ thūlaṁ, idaṁ saṇhaṁ, idaṁ ghanaṁ, idaṁ tanukaṁ, idaṁ paribhuttaṁ, idaṁ aparibhuttaṁ, idaṁ dīghato ettakaṁ puthulato ettaka’nti evaṁ vatthāni vicinitvā. Tulayitvāti ‘idaṁ ettakaṁ agghati, idaṁ ettakan’ti evaṁ agghaparicchedaṁ katvā. ‘Vaṇṇāvaṇṇaṁ katvā’ti ‘sace sabbesaṁ ekekameva dasagghanakaṁ pāpuṇāti, iccetaṁ kusalaṁ; no ce pāpuṇāti, yaṁ nava vā aṭṭha vā agghati, taṁ aññena ekaagghanakena ca dviagghanakena ca saddhiṁ bandhitvā etena upāyena same paṭivīse ṭhapetvā’ti attho. ‘Bhikkhū gaṇetvā vaggaṁ bandhitvā’ti ‘sace ekekassa diyamāne divaso nappahoti, dasa dasa bhikkhū gaṇetvā dasa dasa cīvarapaṭivīse ekavaggaṁ bandhitvā ekaṁ bhaṇḍikaṁ katvā evaṁ cīvarapaṭivīsaṁ ṭhapetuṁ anujānāmī’”ti attho, “Uccinitvā means having distinguished the cloth in this way: ‘This is coarse, this is soft, this is thick, this is thin, this is used, this is unused; this is its length and this its width.’ Tulayitvā means dividing it up according to value in this way: ‘This is worth so much, this so much.’ Vaṇṇāvaṇṇaṁ katvā: the meaning is: ‘If each one of them obtains what has a value of ten, it is good. If not, then what has the value of nine or eight should be bound with another (piece) that has the value of one or two, in this way fixing equal shares’. Bhikkhū gaṇetvā vaggaṁ bandhitvā: the meaning is: ‘I allow, if one day is not sufficient to give it out to each one separately, to count the monks in groups of ten, then to bind ten shares of robe-cloth for each group, then to make one bundle, and in this way to fix the shares of robe-cloth.’”

pli-tv-kd8:9.2.5.eng: The monks who were distributors of robe-cloth thought,

pli-tv-kd8:9.2.6.eng: “What share of the robe-cloth should we give to the novices?”

pli-tv-kd8:9.2.8.eng: “I allow you to give half a share to the novices.”

pli-tv-kd8:9.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu sakena bhāgena uttaritukāmo hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:9.3.1.eng: On one occasion a monk wanted to take his own share and leave.
pli-tv-kd8:9.3.1.comm: Uttaritukāma, literally, “desiring to cross over”. Sp 3.343: Uttaritukāmoti nadiṁ vā kantāraṁ vā uttaritukāmo; satthaṁ labhitvā disā pakkamitukāmoti attho, “Uttaritukāmo: means desiring to cross over a river or a wilderness. The meaning is: ‘Having found a caravan, he desires to leave for the districts.’”

pli-tv-kd8:9.3.3.eng: “You should give a share to one who’s leaving.”

pli-tv-kd8:9.3.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu atirekabhāgena uttaritukāmo hoti.
pli-tv-kd8:9.3.4.eng: On another occasion a monk wanted to take an extra share and leave.

pli-tv-kd8:9.3.6.eng: “I allow you to give an extra share to anyone who gives something in return.”

pli-tv-kd8:9.4.2.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho cīvarapaṭivīso dātabbo, āgatapaṭipāṭiyā nu kho udāhu yathāvuḍḍhan”ti?
pli-tv-kd8:9.4.2.eng: “How should we give out the shares of robe-cloth? According to the order in which the monks have arrived or according to seniority?”

pli-tv-kd8:9.4.4.eng: “You should satisfy those in need and then give out the remainder by drawing lots.”
pli-tv-kd8:9.4.4.comm: The meaning of this is not clear. Toseti, which is the causative formation of tussati, means “to please” or “to satisfy” someone. Judging from the usage of this verb elsewhere, it seems to be exclusively used with reference to living beings, that is, the patient of the verb will invariably be a living being. Reading vikalake as an accusative plural, the meaning of vikalake tosetvā might be construed as follows: “to satisfy those who are short (of robes or cloth)”. The meaning of kusapātaṁ kātuṁ, literally, “the kusa-grass should be dropped”, is equally unclear. Yet according to how kusa-grass is used elsewhere as an aid to sharing out requisites (e.g. at Kd 8:24.4.4), I take it to refer to a randomized method for giving out shares of robe-cloth. I translate accordingly. I have added the phrase “give out the remainder” to clarify the overall meaning. The commentary, however, sees most of this quite differently. Sp 3.343: Vikalake tosetvāti … Cīvaravikalakaṁ nāma sabbesaṁ pañca pañca vatthāni pattāni, sesānipi atthi, ekekaṁ pana na pāpuṇāti, chinditvā dātabbāni. … Chinditvā dinne pana taṁ tositaṁ hoti, atha kusapāto kātabbo, “Vikalake tosetvā: … Cīvaravikalaka means when five cloths are obtained by everyone and there are leftovers, but not sufficient for each one, the cloth should be cut up and then given out. … When it is given out after cutting it up, that means the remainder is shared out. Then the kusa-grass should be dropped.”

pli-tv-kd8:10.1.0.eng: 14. Discussion on the dyeing of robes

pli-tv-kd8:10.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū chakaṇenapi paṇḍumattikāyapi cīvaraṃ rajanti.
pli-tv-kd8:10.1.1.eng: At that time the monks dyed the robes even with dung and beige clay.

pli-tv-kd8:10.1.4.eng: “I allow you to use six kinds of dye:

pli-tv-kd8:10.1.5.pli: mūlarajanaṃ, khandharajanaṃ, tacarajanaṃ, pattarajanaṃ, puppharajanaṃ, phalarajanan”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:10.1.5.eng: dye from roots, dye from wood, dye from bark, dye from leaves, dye from flowers, and dye from fruit.”

pli-tv-kd8:10.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū sītudakāya cīvaraṃ rajanti.
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.1.eng: The monks dyed the robes in cold water.

pli-tv-kd8:10.2.4.eng: “I allow a dye-pot to boil the dye.”

pli-tv-kd8:10.2.7.eng: “I allow you to attach a collar.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.7.comm: Sp 3.344: Uttarāḷumpanti vaṭṭādhārakaṁ, rajanakumbhiyā majjhe ṭhapetvā taṁ ādhārakaṁ parikkhipitvā rajanaṁ pakkhipituṁ anujānāmīti attho. Evañhi kate rajanaṁ na uttarati, “Uttarāḷumpa: the meaning is a circular collar; having fixed it on the middle of the dyeing-pot, having made a circle of it, you should add the dye. For when it is done in this way, the dye does not overflow.” Sp-ṭ 3.344 specifies that the collar goes inside the pot, antorajanakumbhiyā. Vmv 3.344 adds: Evañhi kateti vaṭṭādhārassa anto rajanodakaṁ, bahi challikañca katvā viyojane kate. Na uttaratīti kevalaṁ udakato pheṇuṭṭhānābhāvā na uttarati, “‘For when it is done in this way’ means: after placing the dyeing water inside the circular collar and the (dyeing-)bark on the outside, they are kept separate. ‘It does not overflow’ means: the foam rising completely from the water does not overflow.”

pli-tv-kd8:10.2.8.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū na jānanti rajanaṃ pakkaṃ vā apakkaṃ vā.
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.8.eng: The monks did not know whether the dye was ready or not.

pli-tv-kd8:10.2.10.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, udake vā nakhapiṭṭhikāya vā thevakaṃ dātun”ti.
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.10.eng: “You should put a drop in water or on the back of your nail.”

pli-tv-kd8:10.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū rajanaṃ oropentā kumbhiṃ āviñchanti.
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.1.eng: To empty the pot, the monks tilted it.
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.1.comm: Reading āvajjanti with the PTS edition.

pli-tv-kd8:10.3.4.eng: “I allow a dye-ladle, with or without a handle.”

pli-tv-kd8:10.3.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhūnaṃ rajanabhājanaṃ na saṃvijjati.
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.5.eng: The monks did not have a vessel for the dye.

pli-tv-kd8:10.3.7.eng: “I allow a basin for dye, a waterpot for dye.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.7.comm: Vin-ālaṅ-ṭ 34.57: Tattha rajanakolambanti rajanakuṇḍaṁ. Tattha rajanakuṇḍanti pakkarajanaṭṭhapanakaṁ mahāghaṭaṁ, “There the rajanakolamba is a rajanakuṇḍa. There the rajanakuṇḍa is a large waterpot (ghaṭa) for the placing of finished dye.”
